Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Foundations of Cyber-Physical Infrastructure for Creative Design and Making of Cyber-physical Products

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding for establishing the scientific foundations of a product innovation process that can engage a vastly larger pool of talent to generate new ideas and to create new cyber-physical products. The primary objective is to address fundamental issues pertaining to natural interfaces, behavioral modeling and secure knowledge sharing, with particular emphasis on their integration. This objective will be achieved by pursuing the following three aims: (1) reducing barriers to participation in product innovation through natural interfaces between physical and virtual domains, (2) reducing barriers to model-based engineering in community-based product development, (3) overcoming information-related impediments to collaboration and information sharing. The findings will be embodied in a proof-of-concept cyber-physical platform for creative design and prototyping.

The results of this research hold promise for a new conceptualization of a cyber-physical infrastructure, building on the developments in natural interfaces and information security. The specific outcomes include: (a) well-founded methods for 3D design support of cyber-physical products, and their software embodiment in a natural user interface, (b) techniques and middleware to support model-based engineering in virtual community-based product development, and (c) techniques and protocols for minimum disclosure interactions, quality of inputs assurance, provenance and integrity, and usage control for virtual design and making of cyber-physical products. The proposed research will advance the state of the art in shape creation, product design and manufacturing, and secure design coordination. Validation of the concepts in an educational context will benefit the engineering curriculum by exposing students to emerging ways of designing and making cyber-physical products. Over the long term, the research, education, and dissemination efforts conducted in this project will facilitate a paradigm shift where cyber-physical design and manufacturing using natural interfaces, secure behavioral modeling and knowledge sharing in communities will become a part of our nation?s creative design and manufacturing capacity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has resulted in foundations of cyber-physical infrastructure for creative design and making of realizable products. Fundamental challenges pertaining to natural interfaces, engineering computations, and secure knowledge sharing were addressed in this project. The outcomes of the project enable virtual communities of designers to collaboratively build and test cyber-physical products and systems from the early stages of design where invention can happen leading to innovative products.

Intellectual Merit:

The project has resulted in methodologies and tools that reduce the barrier to participation of individuals in design and making through natural interfaces between physical and virtual domains. These include (i) a novel design paradigm that leverages users’ manual dexterity to hold and expressively manipulate physical objects to provide meaningful spatial inputs into a virtual 3D design application, (ii) a novel embodied interaction paradigm for the expression of design intent for shape deformation, and (iii) methodologies and tools for investigating, understanding, and evaluating human motion patterns in shape modeling activities. The tools reduce the requirements of learning complex modeling and simulation software, and facilitate broader design community from participating in early exploratory stages of design. Using these tools, novice designers can almost immediately learn and begin using them with minimal training and practice. The integration of physically mediated spatial interactions within 3D modeling systems demonstrates how simple and ordinary objects can be used to provide high-level inputs within a virtual design environment without the need for considerable training or practice.

The project has resulted in a secure co-design (SCD) framework that facilitates designers and engineers, including non-security experts, to preserve the confidentiality of their sensitive information while performing product realization activities such as concept generation, design selection, engineering analyses, design optimization, and supplier selection in collaborative settings. As the complexity and multidisciplinary nature of the products and systems increase, information exchange often crosses corporate and national boundaries. The framework developed in this project prevents any leakage of proprietary information in collaborative design, thereby preventing loss of intellectual property and competitive edge of engineering firms. A proof-of-concept of the framework shows how the SCD framework can be implemented for different kinds of engineering collaborations, and that the framework is computationally lightweight, and uses less bandwidth than existing approaches.

The SCD framework is based on lightweight secret sharing protocols as building blocks to construct the desired computations in co-design settings. The novelty of the computation architecture of the secret sharing protocols is that the involvement of a data owner is necessary whenever computations are performed on their inputs. This allows designers to monitor the use of their confidential inputs and thereby avoid any computations that they did not approve of. Such tight control of sensitive datasets would would allow designers to overcome their fear of misuse in and thereby overcome their inhibitions by the co-designers and bring new and sensitive datasets into the collaboration. Such new information would allow collaborators to achieve the full potential of the collaboration while hiding their data.

The project has also resulted in new techniques for counterfeit detection among metal goods based on the metal’s inherent microstructure. New physically unclonable function (PUF) schemes have been developed for counterfeit detection among brass and steel parts that leverage phase and geometric data captured through surface micrographs taken with an optical microscope. The technique is robust to moderate damage that may be experienced in service.

Broader Impacts:

The project has supported the training and education of five graduate students. One of the PhD students supported by this project has gone on to become a tenure-track faculty member within the US, and will be continuing research activities in related areas. Other students have taken up positions within industry. The results from this project have been disseminated through journal and conference publications, and have been presented to the engineering design and computer science communities. The outcomes of the project have applications beyond the domain of engineering design and making. The secure computation framework developed as part of this project can be used in the healthcare domain. The computationally lightweight nature of the developed protocols allows the computations involved in benchmarking of hospitals or physicians to be performed in real time and thereby providing actionable insights to participating health facilities on various factors, including patient population characteristics and the presence of care gaps at a facility. The use of secure computations unlocks the potential to perform statistical analyses on sensitive datasets such as patient data while complying with data sharing regulations.
